manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: ELP 16megapixel wide angle usb camera with 120degree no distortion lens for computer,pc,laptop. ELP-USB16MP01-H120 (H120 No distion Lens, HFOV 118degree) Based on 1/2.8" 16MP IMX298 image sensor, Fixed focus, No distortion lens, UVC compliant USB 2.0 cameras. This is a mini webcam module, Max resolution 16 Mega pixel 4656 x 3496 output, with 38*38/32*32mm mini board size. No extra drivers are needed, the native UVC drivers of Windows, Linux, and Mac shall be compatible with this camera.Manual control the focusing process to capture the still object,shots the imaging and video you want.Ultra HD resolution meets your request for higher quality video still pictures resolution.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Works perfectly with LightBurn software and my 60 watt laser.
reviews.reviewText: I've been using Lightburn for over a year and have wanted to add a camera to the setup for some time, but the Lightburn cameras were a little too pricey for my taste, esp. knowing there were better options. After doing a lot of research I finally landed on this little guy and I am not disappointed. The camera has a very wide 118 degree angle of view that allowed me to mount it under the lid and still be able to see the entire 20"x28" work area clearly. The unit ships as just a tiny camera mounted to a tiny PC board, so knowing it needed a case, I decided to use my skill as a 3D artist and 3D print one. It turned out perfect, its about the same size as a business card, and very easily mounted to the lid using high quality double sided tape. Once I had it attached, I ran the USB cable to the PC, plugged it in and the camera installed all by itself, no problems and no driver, it just worked. So in Lightburn I selected the option '16mp USB Camera' in 'Settings' and went through the calibration process and within about 20 minutes I was up and running. It really is great being able to accurately place materials on the cutting bed and locate them visually in the interface. I think next I'm gonna have to install better LED lighting so that will allow features like the auto trace to work too, bit for now I'm happy with this simple and overall fairly inexpensive upgrade to my system. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good quality USB camera
reviews.reviewText: This 16MP wide angle USB camera is a remarkable piece of technology designed for Raspberry Pi, computers, and the Jetson Nano. With a 16MP resolution and 4K video capability, this camera module delivers high-quality images and videos.The 118-degree no distortion lens ensures a wide field of view without compromising the image quality. The high-quality sensor further enhances the image clarity, making it suitable for various applications including industrial PC and Lightburn camera setups.The module’s compatibility with USB2.0 makes it easy to connect with various devices. Its compact size makes it a perfect fit for laptops and other space-constrained setups.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good camera for Lightburn, with some caveats
reviews.reviewText: Overall this is a nice camera. High resolution, decent frame rates, very wide angle. You'll probably want some sort of case for it - I designed and 3D printed one. If you don't have access to something like that consider the environment you're putting it in and whether it will be OK as a bare board. Nice camera and I'm happy with it.However, I mainly I picked this up to use with LightBurn in my laser enclosure. It probably works fine with Windows and Mac, but I'm using it under Linux and had some problems. In general it works great with Linux in other apps (e.g. Cheese, a simple webcam app). But as I understand it, LightBurn on Linux is still a 32bit app. I was getting errors in the console when running that there was an allocation error. Long story short, LightBurn on Linux can't handle this camera's max resolution, and it doesn't have a way to selected a lower resolution. I found a workaround that mostly works if you check the LightBurn forums. Be forewarned if you're considering this camera for the same application. You may want to look for a lower resolution model. I think anything 2K or lower works fine.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I have checked this camera on my Windows computer and it works well. The project planned for this camera will be to connect to a raspberry Pi using Octo-print software to give me real time monitoring and provide some remote control of my 3D printer. This should save me many trips up and down the stairs. I will update this review after I get some time to tackle this project.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I have someone of a man cave shed that has more and more valuable stuff. I had a small form factor computer in there anyways, so I figured if I attached the camera to it I could make a security system of sorts out of it. Still playing around with various software packages, but it does have pretty decent video capture for my intended use. Note; using with Windows 11.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Works well enough
reviews.reviewText: I'd hoped to use this in a specific application, but, unfortunately, the locked focus doesn't allow it. Disappointed in that, for sure. As a plain camera, printing up a housing for it was no problem, many designs exist. Mostly, I use it for monitoring the interior of one of my laser enclosures, where the balance of light and lack of focus adjustment aren't a problem.
